title-group.article-title: An Analysis of SEC Guidelines for Executing Open Market Repurchases*

abstract.p: Rule 10b‐18 is the only guidance the Securities and Exchange Commission provides for open market stock repurchases. Fashioned as a safe harbor without disclosure, 10b‐18 conformity is unverifiable with public data. We use privately disclosed data to document claimed and actual compliance. While the level of compliance is relatively high, only two firms in our sample consistently comply for all repurchases. Even firms that publicly declared compliance violate the safe harbor's bounds. We document that violations of the safe harbor are more likely to occur following price declines. Our investigation questions the regulatory effectiveness of safe harbors without mandatory disclosure.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of open market repurchases has risen dramatically in recent years. According to Ikenberry, Lakonishok, and Vermaelen (2000), between 1996 and 1998 over 4,000 firms announced open market repurchase programs for roughly $550 billion, compared to an average of $25 billion of repurchases per year in the 1980s. There are extensive rules and regulations policing trading in a firm’s stock. For example, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) requires insiders to disclose both ownership and trading activity on a monthly basis.1Additionally, Bettis, Coles, and Lemmon (2000) report that over 92% of firms have some type of policy restricting trading by insiders, and 78% have explicit blackout periods when trading is prohibited. In contrast, a corporation’s trading in its own stock through open market repurchasing is relatively unregulated. The only guide for executing open market repurchases is SEC safe harbor Rule 10b‐18 under the Exchange Act of 1934. Rule 10b‐18 describes a code of conduct that, if followed, provides a corporation protection against stock price manipulation charges based solely on the timing or price of repurchases. While 10b‐18 affords corporations protection related to manipulation charges, the SEC has clearly stated that repurchasing while in possession of favorable, material nonpublic information is not immune from Rule 10b‐5 fraud charges. Corporate repurchasers must therefore “disclose or abstain.”

An important difference between the SEC’s regulatory approach to insider trading and that for repurchasing is that there are extensive, cumbersome public disclosure requirements for the former and a total absence of disclosure requirements or guidelines for the latter. In the usual course of business, the SEC and other interested parties have no means of investigating 10b‐18 compliance.

It seems fairly clear that Rule 10b‐18’s combination of a safe harbor with voluntary (potentially strategic) disclosure contributes to, if not dictates, the lack of post‐10b‐18 repurchase‐related lawsuits and SEC investigations. What is not clear is whether the lack of lawsuits and investigations is due to 10b‐18 conformity (a lack of manipulative behavior) or the inability of interested parties to amass sufficient data to compel further disclosure. Even when the repurchasing corporation has made a formal statement of an intent to comply with 10b‐18, it is not possible to determine (using publicly available data sources) whether firms are acting in concert with their stated intentions.

Since the enactment of Rule 10b‐18 in 1982, the SEC has been quiet about the regulation of open market repurchases with one notable exception regarding liquidity provision during severe market declines. In 1987, following the October 19 “market break,” SEC chairman David Ruder encouraged companies to buy back their stock by announcing that the SEC was taking a flexible attitude toward buybacks done outside of the commission’s antimanipulation “safe harbor” guidelines.2While the statement proffered a flexible attitude on behalf of the SEC enforcement division, there is no evidence that the SEC has ever acted in any other manner. There have been no lawsuits or other actions taken by the SEC regarding manipulative behavior surrounding open market repurchases since the adoption of 10b‐18. We argue that this may be partly due to the structure of the regulation.

Public declarations of intended Rule 10b‐18 compliance have increased from only two in 1985 to a total of 57 in 1997 and 1998. In spite of the low numbers, Wall Street traders believe that most firms do follow 10b‐18.3Additionally, the following commentary was provided on the recently enacted amendment to 10b‐18:
The Commission [SEC] estimates that each year there are approximately 1,455 issuers effecting 1,730 share repurchase programs, or on average 1.2 repurchase programs per issuer, in accordance with Rule 10b‐18 safe harbor.
The NYSE [New York Stock Exchange] acknowledged that Rule 10b‐18 is neither mandatory nor the exclusive means for an issuer to make repurchases without manipulating the market price of its securities. However, it noted that in practice many issuers are reluctant to undertake repurchases without the certainty that their bids and purchases fall within the Rule 10b‐18 safe harbor.4
Thus, while it is commonly believed by traders, the SEC, and the exchanges, that the safe harbor is being followed, no evidence has ever been gathered to support this position. Using privately disclosed data, we perform the first investigation of claimed and actual 10b‐18 compliance for 54 firms.

We find that firms are generally in compliance with the safe harbor on the majority of their repurchases. However, we document that only two of 54 firms were verifiably in compliance with the safe harbor guidelines for all reported repurchasing. Twenty‐two firms traded outside of the volume limitation on at least one occasion. Forty‐seven of the 54 firms traded outside the pricing provision on over 20% of the trades. Importantly, even firms that publicly declared an intent to comply with Rule 10b‐18 failed to meet each of the necessary provisions. While evidence of trading outside of the safe harbor does not imply improper conduct on the part of repurchasing firms, it does call into question the widespread belief that firms voluntarily comply with 10b‐18 for all open market repurchase programs.

We examine stock performance surrounding repurchases made in compliance with the safe harbor and compare those to repurchases outside of Rule 10b‐18. Overall, consistent with the findings of Ikenberry et al. (2000) on Canadian repurchases, we find negative abnormal performance on repurchase days. We document negative abnormal returns of −22 basis points on days when repurchases are not in compliance with 10b‐18 (for NYSE traded stocks) compared to −10 basis points on repurchase days that are in full compliance with the safe harbor. We also find that firms increase repurchasing and increase the probability of trading outside of the safe harbor following periods of price declines. These findings are consistent with the notion that firms become more aggressive in repurchasing following price drops, apparently intentionally trading outside of the safe harbor either to buy when the stock price is low or to provide liquidity during periods of sell pressure.

The remainder of the article is as follows. Section II discusses the history of repurchase regulation and lays out the provisions of Rule 10b‐18 relevant to the subsequent empirical investigation. Section III describes our data set. Section IV examines whether corporations comply with Rule 10b‐18, considers whether firms’ compliance assertions accord with their practices, and examines stock returns on complying and noncomplying repurchase days. Section V offers concluding remarks.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: A History of Repurchase Regulation
sec.p: The original impetus for regulating open market repurchases came from the federal court ruling inSEC v. Georgia‐Pacific(CCH sec. 91,692 [S.D.N.Y. 1966]). Between 1961 and 1966, Georgia‐Pacific acquired other companies using its common stock as payment. The number of shares to be exchanged in these transactions was contingent on the price level reached during a specified trading period. The SEC charged that Georgia‐Pacific had used open market repurchases to manipulate (increase) the reference sale price, thereby reducing the number of shares needed to effect the acquisitions. The court issued an injunction restraining Georgia‐Pacific from repurchasing any shares while the terms of an acquisition or exchange offer were being determined. It also significantly restricted Georgia‐Pacific’s open market activity at other times. These actions produced a general fear of SEC actions related to repurchase programs and widespread uncertainty regarding what constituted acceptable repurchase executions.

In 1967, the U.S. Senate debated a bill to regulate repurchase programs. The bill argued that regulation was necessary because “whatever the motive behind a repurchase program, if the repurchases are substantial they will have a significant impact on the market price of the securities. The shareholders of the company and other persons interested in the market price of its stock should have full information regarding the company’s activities and intentions in repurchasing its own stock.”5Congress, as a part of the Williams Act of 1968, enacted Securities Exchange Act 13(e)(1):
It shall be unlawful for an issuer which has a class of equity securities registered pursuant to Section 12 of this title, or which is a closed‐end investment company registered under the Investment Company Act, to purchase any equity security issued by it if such purchase is in contravention of such rules and regulations as the Commission, in the public interest or for protection of investors, may adopt (A) to define acts and practices which are fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative, and (B) to prescribe means reasonably designed to prevent such acts and practices. Thus, the original legislative intent was for the SEC to define fraudulent, deceptive, and manipulative uses of repurchase programs and to establish means to prevent such use. It is clear from the historical record that fostering public disclosure of relevant repurchase‐related information was an important feature of this legislation.

In accordance with this mandate, in 1970 the SEC proposed Rule 13e‐2 and submitted it for public comment. The initial version prohibited issuers from using repurchases to raise market prices or create the appearance of widespread interest through the proliferation of brokers or the domination of trading. In 1973, a revision was distributed for comments specifically related to disclosure requirements. Since 13e‐2 had extensive proscriptive restrictions on repurchases, it is not surprising that some commentators questioned the need for extensive disclosure. Lipton (1974) states, “In response to the Commission’s request contained in the release proposing Rule 13e‐2, comments submitted on disclosure have noted that the various volume, price and timing limitations on purchases by the issuer, which are contained in the proposed Rule 13e‐2, serve to eliminate or greatly reduce the market effect of the issuer’s repurchases and accordingly reduce the materiality, and the need for disclosure, of the repurchase program.” It is important to note that the argument was that proscriptive regulation and disclosures were not simultaneously needed. Proscriptions and disclosures were positioned as competing remedies to the regulation of open market repurchases. As such, the argument was for either required disclosure under a voluntary safe harbor, or less, if any, disclosure under proscriptive regulation. The final revision of 13e‐2 came in 1980. Feller and Chamberlin (1984, p. 994) note, “The 1980 release stressed the Commission’s view that disclosure alone could not take the place of substantive regulation in this area, and that structuring the rule as a safe harbor would not sufficiently deter improper issuer conduct.”

On November 17, 1982, after 13 years of debate, the SEC executed a complete regulatory “about‐face.” The commission adopted safe harbor Rule 10b‐18 and abandoned mandatory compliance and disclosure. In contrast to other SEC regulations that link safe harbors with disclosure (e.g., earlier in 1982, the SEC implemented Regulation D with Form D, and Rule 144 has its Form 144), 10b‐18 conformity is essentially unverifiable to the public, the exchanges, and the SEC, without additional voluntary or involuntary corporate disclosure. Rule 10b‐18 remains in effect today.

sec.title: Provisions of Rule 10b‐18
sec.p: It is important to note that Rule 10b‐18 does not provide protection for a corporation if it is trading based on material nondisclosed information.6Thus, if firms are in possession of material nonpublic information, they have the choice of disclosing the information or abstaining from repurchasing.

fn.p: With regard to using multiple brokers on one day, four of the 54 firms in our sample provided information revealing that they employed multiple brokers on a given day. In terms of the trading volume limitations, Krigman (1997) demonstrates that interdealer transactions create significant volume inflation in dealer markets. Thus, NASDAQ firms may face a less binding volume constraint relative to NYSE‐listed firms. While reported trading volume generated by different trading mechanisms is widely acknowledged to be noncomparable, SEC Rule 10b‐18 continues to employ volume as a policy instrument.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: The Repurchase Data Set
sec.p: Detailed firm‐specific repurchase data are not disclosed to the public or the SEC. To investigate Rule 10b‐18 compliance, privately disclosed data are necessary. We directly solicited corporations for repurchase data. We requested data from 478 firms identified in Securities Data Corporation’s (SDC) Mergers and Acquisitions Database, which announced open market repurchase programs between March 10, 1993, and March 4, 1994.7Sixty‐eight firms responded to our request for data. Four of the 68 corporations indicated that they were unable or unwilling to provide the requested data. We exclude 10 responding firms that had merger and acquisition activity announced during the period of our study.8The remaining 54 firms constitute the sample used in our study.9One firm changed listing from the NASDAQ (National Association of Security Dealers Automated [system]) to the NYSE during the repurchase program, and consequently our final sample includes 55 repurchase programs, 19 NYSE programs and 36 NASDAQ programs.

Firms provided the target dollar amount of the program, the target number of shares, the status of the program, the position title or agent designated to coordinate the repurchase activity, and the name of a contact person. The disclosed trading data include the trading dates, the exchange on which the trades were executed, the daily number of shares repurchased, the price paid per share, and an indication of whether each price reported is an aggregate or exact price.

We undertook a two‐stage verification procedure to assure the accuracy of the data. Initially, we checked the reported volume against total daily volumes from the NYSE Transactions and Quotations (TAQ) Dataset. When infeasible transactions were discovered, we directly contacted the corporations for clarification. The most common inconsistencies were due to reporting settlement rather than trade dates and including brokerage commissions in prices. After incorporating corrections, we used daily price‐volume summaries calculated from the TAQ data to assure price‐volume feasibility of all reported trades. We exclude eight reported transactions from six firms that were not feasible and where no resolution was found, 42 repurchase days in 1992 (prior to the availability of TAQ data), and eight trades that were reported as private transactions. Our final data set includes 60.9 million shares repurchased on 1,997 trade days across 54 firms in 1993 and 1994.

Due to the structure of Rule 10b‐18, verifying compliance requires identification of repurchases at the transaction level. While some firms provided detailed transactions level data, many firms provided daily trading summaries. Thus, we employ combinatorial programming to “identify” repurchase transactions within the TAQ data set. AppendixCcontains details of our procedure. Overall, of the 60.9 million shares reported to us, we “identify” over 30 million shares. This is the subsample used to investigate compliance with the price and timing conditions of 10b‐18.

Table1presents summary statistics on the data set. Our sample, while small, represents a wide cross section of the market. The 1993 annual trading volume for these firms ranges from 8.2 million shares to over 24 billion shares traded, with an average of 2.8 billion shares. The market capitalization of the firms ranges from $6 million to over $31 billion. The firms exhibit diversity in the level of repurchase aggression (as proxied by the percent of the total daily volume acquired in one day: .03%–100%) and the firm’s percent of outstanding shares targeted (.56%–32.8%). The frequency of repurchase is highly variable across firms. One firm repurchased on only one day, whereas one large firm executed repurchases on 288 of 325 consecutive days. Repurchases are executed on an average of 34.5% of the trading days between the first and last reported repurchase day. The length of the reported repurchase horizon ranges from one to 387 trade days. Interestingly, the firms in our sample waited an average of 17 days from announcement to the first repurchase, with a range of one to 124 days. The use of survey data can always be subject to criticism, even when the survey data are verifiable (as with repurchase trades). However, we feel that it is important to weigh the potential gain in our understanding of issues not currently addressable with publicly available data sets against any possible overgeneralizations fostered by potential self‐selection bias. Without an SEC‐ or Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB)‐directed change in repurchase disclosure requirements, survey is the only technique available for examining voluntary compliance with the safe harbor. Ultimately, the possibility of self‐selection bias remains, and all results should be interpreted with this in mind.

fn.p: With respect to self‐selection bias, it seems reasonable to assume that responding firms would be more likely to comply with Rule 10b‐18 than nonresponding firms. The data were solicited for the purpose of general studies relating to NASDAQ and NYSE repurchase execution. While several respondents mentioned Rule 10b‐18, our solicitation did not. In this analysis, we include data on the full set of 64 firms that provided repurchase data. We do not exclude the 10 firms involved in mergers and acquisitions activity.

sec.title: Do Firms Comply with Rule 10b‐18?
sec.p: Of the 54 firms in our sample, 52 trade outside of Rule 10b‐18 restrictions on at least one occasion. Of the 1,997 firm trade days, noncompliance occurs on 591, or 29.6%, of the repurchase days. In the exactly identified subset, 32 firms trade outside of the safe harbor on 289, or 14.4%, of the days.11Thus, some firms are either opting out of the safe harbor or their trades are being improperly executed.

Volume Limit Compliance. The most frequently cited condition of Rule 10b‐18 has to do with the allowable repurchase volume on any given day.12The rule limits nonblock purchases for a day to 25% of the security’s trading volume. We find that 22 of 54 firms exceed 10b‐18 allowable volume on at least one occasion.

An important feature of Rule 10b‐18’s trading volume restriction is that it is self‐referential: average daily trading volume is calculated exclusive of past corporate block repurchases, but the definition of block repurchases is (partially) defined by the average daily trading volume. The exact language of the rule states:
Definition 1. A security’strading volumeis the security’s average consolidated daily trading volume, exclusive of Rule 10b‐18 block purchases (defined below), in the four calendar weeks preceding the week of a Rule 10b‐18 purchase or bid.
Definition 2. The termblockmeans a quantity of stock that either has (i) a purchase price of at least $200,000; (ii) comprises at least 5,000 shares with a purchase price of at least $50,000; (iii) is at least 2,000 shares and constitutes at least 150% of the trading volume (defined above) for that security.

The rationale for the definitional structure is clear. Repurchasing firms have an incentive to inflate volume early in a program to make the path‐dependent future volume limitations less binding. One way to reduce this incentive is to exclude corporate block repurchases when calibrating trading volume benchmarks. While this exclusion is simple in concept, it imposes a rather onerous data requirement on any outsider wishing to ascertain Rule 10b‐18 compliance. For an insider possessing the entire history of a firm’s transaction‐specific repurchase activity, it is straightforward to construct the required time series of daily volumes excluding corporate blocks:
1.
Starting with the first repurchase day, examine the four preceding calendar weeks to determine the daily volume. (Since an insider has the entire repurchase history, he can be sure that there is no repurchase activity in the previous four calendar week period.)
2.
Average the daily consolidated volumes during the four calendar week period.
3.
Multiply this average by 1.5 to determine which execution‐level identified corporate repurchases qualify as type (iii) blocks, previously defined as at least 2,000 shares and at least 150% of the trading volume.
4.
Determine which execution‐level identified repurchase transactions qualify as type (i) blocks, defined by a purchase price of at least $200,000, and type (ii) blocks, defined by at least 5,000 shares with a purchase price of at least $50,000.
5.
Subtract the sum of volumes in type i, ii, and iii corporate blocks from that day’s consolidated volume to determine the amount of volume that will be used in step 2 on future dates.

By iterating this process into the future, an insider can accurately and precisely determine whether the firm is complying with Rule 10b‐18 volume restrictions. However, we (and the SEC) are not insiders. The firms in our sample did not disclose their entire history of transaction‐specific repurchase activity. To our knowledge, no multifirm data set containing such an extensive disclosure exists. Thus, the insider procedure we outline above is not directly implementable. As such, we construct a procedure to accommodate limited corporate disclosure.

With repurchases identified by the procedures described in appendixC, we check if identified prints are blocks and, if so, omit them to obtain corporate nonblock volume for the day. The effect of this omission, for the current day, is unambiguous. Nonblock volume is lower, and the volume limitation is less binding. However, this omission results in two opposite effects on detecting future excess volume: (a) it makes future type iii blocks, as defined above, more likely; (b) it makes future trading volume constraints more binding (lower). Effectadecreases, whereas effectbincreases, the likelihood of future excess volume.

As previously mentioned, identifying each and every repurchase execution (particularly on the NYSE) proves intractable. In order to give the corporation the benefit of the doubt, when checking for current excess volume, the unidentified volume, if feasible as a block, must always be treated as a block. In contrast, to give the corporation the benefit of the doubt when constructing future criteria for type iii blocks (related toaabove) and volume limitations (related tobabove), unidentified volume must be treated differently. With respect to type iii blocks, unidentified volume, if feasible as blocks, must be treated as blocks, making it more likely that future corporate trading is designated as a block and therefore not constrained by 10b‐18. With respect to volume limitation benchmarks, unidentified volume, if feasible as a nonblock, must be treated as a nonblock, resulting in less binding future volume constraints.13

In every case, given the combinatorial identification output (either exactly or algorithmically identified), we treat the unidentified corporate volume in a manner that makes 10b‐18 volume limitations less binding. With algorithmic identification, we almost certainly understate the amount of noncompliance with 10b‐18 volume restrictions. Twenty‐two of the 54 firms in our sample exceed the allowed volume on at least one occasion. Of the 832 repurchase days for these 22 firms, the volume limitation is exceeded on 88 trade days, or 10.6% of the time. In the exactly identified subset, 21 firms trade in excess of allowed volume on 82 trade days. As can be seen in table3, the frequency of violation is higher on the NASDAQ than on the NYSE.14On the NASDAQ, 17 of 36 firms exceed the volume limitation on 70 trade days, or 22.3% of the time. The level of excess volume relative to the allowed level ranges from a low of 25 shares to a high of 12,300 shares. While the absolute number of shares repurchased in excess of allowable 10b‐18 nonblock volume appears low, for the full sample of firms, the average volume violation represents repurchasing 50.2% more than the allowable volume for the day. On the NYSE, the average violations represent only 14% of allowed volume, whereas on the NASDAQ, firms repurchase 57% more than the allowed nonblock volume for a day. The Rule 10b‐18 timing condition specifies that a firm cannot execute a repurchase at the market open (until an independent transaction has been executed) or during the last half hour of trading for reporting on the consolidated system. Again, our inability to identify affiliated transactions inhibits our ability to identify opening violations. Consider the second example in appendixC(tableC2). We have identified transaction number 2 as a repurchase; however, transaction number 1 is likely to be affiliated. Thus, the repurchase is a violation of the opening condition but would not be identified as such without knowledge of dependent trading. We find that 17 firms executed 46 repurchase transactions at the market open. In the exactly identified subset, six firms executed 10 transactions at the market open. The majority of market open noncompliances occurred for NYSE firms; 13 firms executed 39 transactions at the market open. Table4provides details of all timing noncompliances by exchange listing.

The second component of the timing condition rules out transactions during the last half hour of the trading day. The motivation for this rule is to prohibit the firm from directly influencing the closing price of the day. Dealer interpositioning is not an issue with closing price noncompliance. We find that 100 of 2,411 identified trades occurred in the last half hour of trading. Four percent of transactions on the NYSE, from 16 firms, and 2.8% of NASDAQ transactions, from eight firms, occurred during the last half hour of trading. Within the exactly identified subset, 11 market close violations occurred on the NASDAQ for five firms.

Overall, of the 2,411 identified repurchase transactions, 587, or 24.3%, were executed outside of Rule 10b‐18’s timing and pricing conditions. We find that only four firms proved to be in compliance with the pricing and timing provisions on all occasions. Given the widespread repurchasing outside of 10b‐18, even in the exactly identified subset, an important question is whether corporations intend to comply and fail in the execution, or have no intent to comply.

fn.p: The exactly identified subset is defined by the following procedure: we ran exhaustive combinations on the subset of reported repurchases where (i) there were not more than 30 prints in the TAQ data for the day, or (ii) there were not more than 100 TAQ prints and not more than 3,000 shares repurchased for the day. This search identifies 475 trades. These must be repurchases if the firms responded accurately to our request for data. Thus, this subset of repurchases is not subject to our identification algorithm. We use it for verification of results from the broader data set.

For example, Brealey and Myers (1996, p. 420) roughly summarize the restrictions: “Many repurchased shares are acquired in the open market. This activity is regulated by the SEC, which requires that the purchases not coincide with issues of stock or private negotiations to buy stock. The SEC also sets guidelines for how the repurchases are carried out. For example, repurchases cannot exceed a stated portion of trading in a company’s stock.”

An additional difficulty arises for firms that (1) disclosed repurchases starting in the middle of an ongoing program or (2) had previous repurchase programs potentially contiguous to the one they reported to us. In these cases, we do not know if the four calendar weeks prior to the disclosed program contain nondisclosed repurchases. For these cases, to give the corporation the benefit of the doubt, we assume all potential blocks in the preceding 4 weeks are corporate when we set the trading volume for type iii blocks in the future. We assume that none of the blocks in the preceding 4 weeks are corporate in calibrating historical trading volume.
This may be a result of our inability to identify corporate executions on the NYSE due to computing constraints.

Identification of all corporate repurchases is required to avoid misclassifying pricing and timing noncompliance. Our inability to identify every repurchase transaction therefore can result in an overstatement of pricing noncompliance; e.g., if the current bid is $9.75, and three trades take place as follows: (1) an independent transaction executes at $10.25, (2) an unidentified repurchase executes at $9.75, and (3) an identified repurchase executes at $10.00. Relative to the last sale (the unidentified repurchase), the $10.00 repurchase appears to be a violation, but relative to the last independent transaction, the repurchase is in accord with the safe harbor. Under these circumstances, our limited ability to exhaustively identify repurchase executions may introduce apparent noncompliance. Another difficulty in ex post identification of pricing violations on the NASDAQ relates to the multiple market‐maker trading structure. With more than one market maker entering trades, it is possible that repurchase transactions are executed in accord with 10b‐18’s conditions although intervening transactions recorded by other market makers create technical noncompliance.

sec.title: Do Firms Think They Comply with 10b‐18?
sec.p: Of the 54 firms in our data set, six indicated that they execute open market repurchases in compliance with Rule 10b‐18. The statements are documented in either (i) the announcement of the repurchase program, (ii) the response to our questionnaire, or (iii) publicly available documents filed with, or in correspondence with, the SEC. For these six firms, we compare stated corporate intent with actual compliance. It is important to note that some firms in our sample indicate that they delegate compliance to a broker. Accordingly, we cannot distinguish corporate‐intended noncompliance from lack of diligence on the part of a broker. Additionally, as our previous discussion highlights, proper delegation to a broker requires that the broker be given the entire repurchase history, at least back to a 4‐week break in repurchasing, to determine allowable volume. The complexity of the calculations in the absence of this history may contribute to a corporation’s failure to realize its intent.

We find that each of the six firms that declared 10b‐18 compliance executed repurchases outside of the safe harbor’s provisions on at least one occasion. Two firms have volume noncompliance, one NYSE and one NASDAQ, on 13 days. Five firms have pricing noncompliance on a total of 37 transactions. Four firms have an open or closing noncompliance. In the subset of firms with exactly identified repurchases, each firm fails to comply with Rule 10b‐18 on at least one occasion. Details are contained in table5. We interpret these results in the context of possible repurchase motives. Suppose that, on large down days, firms intensify their efforts to support price or buy cheaply (relative to recent price history). As they intensify their efforts during falling prices, firms may be more likely to forgo (inadvertently) Rule 10b‐18’s safe harbor. The result is a correlation between larger negative abnormal returns and noncomplying repurchases. Alternatively, firms may trade outside of the safe harbor to take advantage of information. In this case, we should see violations occurring more frequently in advance of price increases. To further understand trading outside of the safe harbor, we examine cumulative lead and lag returns surrounding both compliant and noncompliant repurchase trading.

We code days of no repurchase (0), days of repurchase trading in compliance with the safe harbor (1), and days of trading in violation of the safe harbor (2). The ordering is considered a measure of degree, with violations considered the most severe. The model is structured to predict the probability of repurchasing in violation of Rule 10b‐18. For the 19 NYSE firms in our sample, we find consistent evidence that these firms are more likely to both repurchase and trade outside of the safe harbor following price declines. The results are robust for the 3‐day, 5‐day, and 10‐day model specification. However, we find no evidence that firms are more likely to violate or repurchase more frequently in advance of price increases. For the NASDAQ, we find only marginal support at the 5‐day window for firms repurchasing and violating more following price declines. Consistent with the findings on the NYSE, we find no support for firms’ using information to repurchase more in advance of price increases. The overall results support the view that NYSE firms are aggressive in repurchasing to provide liquidity during periods of falling markets. They repurchase more, and violate the safe harbor more frequently, following large price declines. This is consistent with Cook, Krigman, and Leach (2003), who provide evidence that, whatever the reason, NYSE firms appear to repurchase into falling prices. While price support was not the specific type of manipulation originally targeted by Congress, 10b‐18 compliance appears to impinge (rightly or wrongly) on a firm’s ability to mitigate significant price declines.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: The only formal guidance the SEC provides corporations executing open market repurchases is Rule 10b‐18, a safe harbor of questionable value in constraining repurchase behavior or establishing credible communication regarding repurchases. We provide the first examination of actual repurchase trading and its relationship to Rule 10b‐18. Although the overall compliance rate with 10b‐18 is relatively high, there is widespread evidence that the guidelines are not followed all of the time. In spite of the self‐selection bias inherent in our sample, we still document that of the 54 firms we evaluate, 52 traded outside the safe harbor at least once over the course of their repurchase program. Twenty‐two firms violated the volume limitations on at least one occasion. Fifty firms apparently violated the pricing and timing provisions. Perhaps surprisingly, each of the firms that publicly declared an intent to comply had some noncompliance.

In reaction to questionable corporate repurchase behavior in the early 1960s, Congress mandated that the SEC regulate repurchase programs to prevent “fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative” practices. After abandoning an initial attempt at proscriptive and disclosure‐oriented regulation (proposed Rule 13e‐2), the SEC adopted safe harbor Rule 10b‐18 with no repurchase‐specific disclosure. Therefore, a repurchasing corporation’s conformity to 10b‐18 is essentially unobservable without supplemental information. We argue that safe harbors should contain provisions compelling relevant disclosure. Such disclosure is necessary to ensure verifiability. As a final point, we suggest that Rule 10b‐18’s structure and current industry practice are not sufficiently well understood to justify conclusions like “many issuers are reluctant to undertake repurchases without the certainty that their bids and purchases fall with Rule 10b‐18’s safe harbor.”17

disp-quote.p: SUMMARY: The Securities and Exchange Commission today is adopting an amendment to Rule 10b‐18 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Rule 10b‐18 provides a “safe harbor” from liability for manipulation under Sections 9(a)(2) and 10(b) of the Exchange Act, and Rule 10b‐5 thereunder, when an issuer or affiliated purchaser of the issuer bids for or buys shares of its common stock in compliance with the Rule’s conditions. In order to improve liquidity during severe market downturns, the amendment modifies the Rule’s timing condition during the trading session immediately following a market‐wide trading suspension. In particular, the safe harbor is now available to an issuer that bids for or purchases its common stock either: from the reopening of trading until the close of trading on the same day as the imposition of the market‐wide trading suspension; or at the next day’s opening, if the market‐wide trading suspension was in effect at the scheduled close of trading. The safe harbor requires that the issuer continue to comply with Rule 10b‐18 conditions governing the manner, price and volume of market purchases of its common stock.

app.label: Appendix C
app.p: To investigate Rule 10b‐18 compliance, all daily repurchase volume should be identified at the transactions level. Most firms in our sample provided aggregate trading volume and average price for a given trading day. Some firms provided daily volume repurchased at a given trading price. For low‐trading‐volume stocks, visual identification of repurchases is straightforward. Consider the following example. On one day, a firm reported repurchasing 31,000 shares at a price of $7.125 per share. Table C1 contains a list of all transactions from the consolidated tape in the stock for the day.

It is relatively easy to identify transaction number 4 as the repurchase. The only feasible execution of 31,000 shares at a price of $7.125 is print number 4. No grouping of trades provides the required price‐volume combination. Thus, print number 4 is uniquely identified as a repurchase. However, not all reported volumes are feasibly executed as a single print. Another corporation reported repurchasing 26,500 shares at an aggregate cost (exclusive of commissions) of $542,437.50. There were five transactions in the stock for the day as shown in table C2.

The only feasible combination of trades that achieves the reported cost‐volume repurchase is with transactions numbers 2 and 5. These are uniquely identified repurchases. This procedure results in perfect identification of repurchases if the responses to our request for data are accurate.

For high‐volume stocks, visual identification is intractable, and computer‐based searching is necessary. Computing constraints dictate that we only search for combinations of up to four trades that, as a portfolio, equal the reported repurchase price and volume. If a repurchase could be uniquely executed as a single print, we identify it as such and discontinue our search. Likewise, if a reported repurchase is not feasible in a single print, but is possible as a unique pairing, we label the pair identified and discontinue our search. Using this sequential heuristic, we identify 1,981 corporate prints: 1,114 singletons, 228 pairs, 85 triplets, and 39 quadruplets across 63 tickers.18

The sequential procedure frequently generated more than one feasible execution combination at a given level of complexity (e.g., 15 pairs). At this point we discontinue our examination of higher complexities and begin a search within the combinations at the given level of complexity. For example, if we are searching for 10,100 shares at $30.00, and we find 15 feasible pairs, each containing the same 10,000 share at $30.00 print but matched with 15 different 100 share at $30.00 prints, we classify the 10,000‐share print as an identified corporate trade and log the reported transaction as a partially identified pair. The 100‐share portion remains unidentified. We identify an additional 674 prints using this within‐complexity procedure.19Details of the combinatorial output are provided in appendixD(tableD1). Overall, of the 3,585 reported repurchases across 2,190 firm days, we identify 2,655 prints on 1,431 firm days representing over 31 million shares.

It is easy to construct examples where this procedure may result in erroneous identification. We offer three defenses:
1.
Misidentification will tend to diminish differences and bias against significance in our tests.
2.
The heuristic is biased toward identifying repurchases in large blocks. The Rule 10b‐18 volume limitation is exclusive of block trades. Thus, the heuristic intentionally biases in favor of current volume compliance.
3.
We ran exhaustive combinations on the subset of reported repurchases where (i) there were not more than 30 prints in the TAQ data for the day or (ii) there were not more than 100 TAQ prints and not more than 3,000 shares repurchased for the day. (The 3,000‐share requirement limited the search to combinations of not more than 30, as prints are reported on TAQ in round lots of 100 shares. The choice of a maximum complexity level of 30 for the exhaustive search was dictated by computing constraints.) The exhaustive search identifies 504 trades. These must be repurchases if the firms responded accurately to our request for data. We replicate all transaction‐specific tests on the exhaustive subset; while the power of the tests decline, all results are qualitatively the same. This subset of repurchase transactions is referred to in the text as the “exactly identified” subset.

fn.p: For one NYSE firm, we only search through combinations of three prints. On one day there were 2,951 transactions in the stock; a search for all combinations of four prints requires examining 3,153,423,033,475 combinations. A National Science Foundation supercomputer failed to process this trade day in 130 hours of run time.
The TAQ data sometimes combine small trades executed at the same time and price into a single print and code these prints “B” as bunched. We exclude bunched trades from our combinatoric procedure.
